comment:
Abstract architecture is always arresting to look at. Focusing on a building's windows and showing it in a way that's different from how you'd normally see it is a great way to capture the audience's attention. It makes your audience think about what they're looking at.
 
 I also like how there's a horizontal line in the middle that creates a certain dimension to the image. If only we could lessen or even remove the glare in the middle. It would also be more impactful if there were fewer shadows at the bottom. Maybe find another angle where there are no other reflections and minimal shadowing. This will create a more cohesive look. With the repetitive nature of the building's windows, it gives an infinite feel in the photograph.
 
 Or even better, this photo would work really well in black and white. That way the details become more uniform and powerful.
 
 Finally, the lamp post in the middle is kind of distracting. Though it blends nicely with the building's facade, it becomes more noticeable once you see it.

editing_action.action: Lessen or remove the glare in the middle.
editing_action.reasoning: The action to lessen or remove glare is implied due to the mention of glare being a flaw. This involves adjusting contrast or brightness in post-processing.

editing_action.action: Reduce shadows at the bottom for more impact.
editing_action.reasoning: The suggestion to reduce shadows is implied as it mentions shadows reducing impact. This involves adjusting tones in post-processing to enhance the image.

editing_action.action: Convert the photo to black and white for uniform and powerful details.
editing_action.reasoning: The suggestion to convert the photo to black and white is explicitly stated and involves applying a filter to change the overall appearance of the image.

editing_action.action: Remove or reposition the lamp post to reduce distraction.
editing_action.reasoning: The action to remove or reposition the lamp post is implied due to it being described as distracting. This involves deleting or moving elements in post-processing.

shooting_action.action: Find another angle to minimize reflections and shadowing.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to find another angle is explicitly stated to minimize reflections and shadowing, which falls under the Camera Position category as it involves changing the camera's perspective.

action_concat:
Find another angle to minimize reflections and shadowing.
Convert the photo to black and white for uniform and powerful details.
Lessen or remove the glare in the middle.
Reduce shadows at the bottom for more impact.
Remove or reposition the lamp post to reduce distraction.

comment:
For a portrait image, the face is a little too zoomed in. It doesn't look flattering for his features. There is very little breathing space in the image. The head is especially cropped abruptly. I suggest including his whole face instead of it being cut off at the forehead. Maybe even include his hands, torso or some background context. A little more zoomed out, basically.
 
 The angle works though. I like that it features the side of his face. The small smirk also makes you wonder what he is looking at. The expression looks candid, which is fantastic for portraiture.

editing_action.action: Zoom out to make the face look more flattering.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the face is too zoomed in and not flattering, suggesting that zooming out would improve the image.

shooting_action.action: Include the whole face and possibly hands, torso, or background context by zooming out.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to include more of the subject's face and possibly hands, torso, or background context by zooming out is explicitly stated as a way to improve the composition.

shooting_action.action: Provide more breathing space and avoid abrupt cropping of the head.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment mentions a lack of breathing space and abrupt cropping, implying that adjusting the composition to include more space would improve the image.

action_concat:
Include the whole face and possibly hands, torso, or background context by zooming out.
Zoom out to make the face look more flattering.
Provide more breathing space and avoid abrupt cropping of the head.

comment:
The flower looks pretty. I like how it was positioned slightly off center to create a little bit of white space on the left, which gives all the focus to the subject.
 
 Color-wise, I find it too warm. I would edit the temperature to make it slightly cooler, bring out the blues a little bit. 
 
 The image is also not that sharp for macrophotography. I understand this is the bokeh effect in action, but I think a sharper focus on the subject could be improved. 
 
 For a close-up of a flower, it would be nice to see the vivid colors and crisp details of the petals, the pistil, etc. I suggest playing around with a larger aperture for a greater depth of field or using a tripod.

editing_action.action: Edit the temperature to make it slightly cooler and bring out the blues.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests editing the temperature to make the image cooler and enhance the blues, indicating a post-processing action.

shooting_action.action: Improve sharpness for macrophotography.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment mentions that the image is not sharp enough for macrophotography, implying that the focus should be improved to achieve better sharpness.

shooting_action.action: Use a larger aperture for greater depth of field.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to use a larger aperture is explicitly stated to achieve greater depth of field and sharper details in the close-up of the flower.

shooting_action.action: Use a tripod for greater depth of field and sharper details.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to use a tripod is explicitly stated to achieve greater depth of field and sharper details in the close-up of the flower.

action_concat:
Edit the temperature to make it slightly cooler and bring out the blues.
Use a larger aperture or a tripod for greater depth of field and sharper details.
Improve sharpness for macrophotography.

comment:
Fantastic image! I love it! The composition is kind of asymmetrical but it works. The colors are perfectly subtle, the shadows of the trees, the branches, and the stones are incredibly evocative. It looks so serene almost like a painting. 
 
 If I could nitpick, I would crop the foreground, especially on the right-hand side and give more space to the branches of the trees. That'll make it more balanced and less heavy on the right-hand side.
 
 Other than that, this is a great image!

editing_action.action: Crop the foreground on the right-hand side and give more space to the branches of the trees to balance the composition.
editing_action.reasoning: The suggestion to crop the foreground, especially on the right-hand side, and give more space to the branches is an explicit action aimed at balancing the composition. The action is clearly stated in the comment.

action_concat: Crop the foreground on the right-hand side and give more space to the branches of the trees to balance the composition.

comment:
It looks like a double exposure situation, or something technically went awry, and now the accident looks like a collage or pop art. It is definitely an interesting image.
 
 My problem, though, is how hazy it is. Might that be intentional? I also cannot make out the details of the statue. Everything kind of blends together. Again, possibly a stylistic choice, one that may not be everyone's cup of tea.
 
 Possibly a good edit would be to make the division symmetrical, like it's cut in between instead of three-fourths of the way, like a half-frame film situation.

comment:
I find the blurry edges of the camera to be weird. Why are the body and the edges of the lens blurred? 
 If we're photographing an object, it's better to have the subject sharp as a tack. Even the EX Sigma logo is blurred. It is best to use a tripod for product photography to have the cleanest images possible.
 
 I find the lighting to be a little dark. The photo needs to be brightened so it shows the details of the image.

shooting_action.action: Brighten the photo to better show the details.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly states that the photo needs to be brightened to show details, which involves adjusting exposure in editing.

shooting_action.action: Use a tripod for product photography to achieve cleaner images.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests using a tripod to improve image quality, which falls under the use of support equipment.

shooting_action.action: Improve focus to eliminate blurry edges of the camera and lens.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment mentions blurry edges as a flaw, implying the need for better focus, which is an implicit action.

shooting_action.action: Ensure the subject is sharp in object photography.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the subject should be sharp, suggesting an improvement in focus, which is an implicit action.

shooting_action.action: Improve focus to make the EX Sigma logo sharp.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment notes the blurriness of the EX Sigma logo, implying a need for better focus, which is an implicit action.

action_concat:
Use a tripod for product photography to achieve cleaner images.
Brighten the photo to better show the details.
Improve focus to eliminate blurry edges of the camera and lens.
Ensure the subject is sharp in object photography.
Improve focus to make the EX Sigma logo sharp.

comment:
My first impression is the crooked glaciers in the background. The photo is tilted. Although it could be a stylistic choice, I think a straight line would make the photo more powerful. It's a nature shot, after all.
 
 Second, the photo is noticeably blurry. I'd sharpen this in post to give more emphasis to all the elements, particularly the glaciers and the silhouette of the man. Or, go totally for the blur and play around with the warmth or coolness of the photo so it's more about the vibe or the feeling of being in nature rather than about the glaciers as subject.
 
 The brown rocks also feel awkward and make the photo heavy on the left side. It would help if we could crop the bottom part of the photo, lessening the foreground, so we'd highlight the grandness of the glaciers in the background.

editing_action.reasoning: The suggestion to make the photo more powerful by straightening it indicates a need to correct the tilt, which falls under transforming the image.

Sharpen the photo in post-processing to emphasize elements.
Experiment with blur and adjust warmth or coolness for a nature vibe.

comment:
This type of landscape photography immediately captures the audience's attention because, at first glance, it may look like an abstract painting. But upon closer inspection, the audience might be surprised to figure out what it really is. The use of the swampy water bed at the bottom, as it reflects the tree branches, creates a widening feel of the whole place, making the landscape much larger than it really is.
 
 I hope the photographer can tweak the colors a little more. Highlighting the green more could make it feel more vibrant to look at. Adjusting the shadows a little more can add to the emotional feel of the landscape.

editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests tweaking the colors to enhance the image, which falls under adjusting saturation as it involves modifying the intensity of colors.

editing_action.action: Highlight the green to make the image feel more vibrant.
editing_action.reasoning: The suggestion to highlight the green is an explicit action to increase the vibrance of the green tones, which is a form of adjusting saturation.

editing_action.action: Adjust the shadows to enhance the emotional feel of the landscape.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly mentions adjusting the shadows to enhance the emotional feel, which involves modifying the tonal range, specifically the shadows.

action_concat:
Tweak the colors to enhance the image.
Highlight the green to make the image feel more vibrant.
Adjust the shadows to enhance the emotional feel of the landscape.

comment:
What a lovely photo! It captures the morning sunlight perfectly—hazy, warm, and airy. I also like that the mountains are showcased in a zigzag fashion so it's not too symmetrical.
 
 The photo is balanced quite nicely, with the background hazier and lighter than the dark hues of the foreground. It's incredible to see the trees lit by the backlight. It creates fantastic depth and contrast, making the photo feel more dimensional.
 
 I would try to increase the contrast of the photo, see if it mutes the super bright light in the background, just a little bit, because as much as it looks very realistic right now, it's also a tad harsh.
 
 Minimal editing in my opinion.

editing_action.action: Increase the contrast to mute the super bright light in the background.
editing_action.reasoning: The action is explicitly stated as a suggestion to increase the contrast to address the issue of the super bright light in the background being a tad harsh.

action_concat: Increase the contrast to mute the super bright light in the background.

comment:
For an interior shot, the composition is quite good. We can see everything important in the bedroom. The side angle is also interesting. It gives dimension to the room rather than a straight, head-on shot.
 
 If I could nitpick, I would have included the whole bottom part of the bed instead of cutting it, and I would also include the whole height of the window/window curtains to make the room look more airy. Though right now, it looks okay too.
 
 The room is well-lit as it is, but it could still benefit from a little brightening in post. However, the image is pixelated, possibly just due to the photo's resolution.

shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests including the full bottom part of the bed and the full height of the window/window curtains to enhance the composition and make the room appear more airy.

Brighten the image slightly in post-processing.

comment:
This photo has a lot of potential. However, it looks bland right now. It doesn't feel alive or interesting. 
 
 The one dimensional light and the overcast do not do the skyline any justice. It would have been more dramatic if it was a night shot, or a golden hour shot, anything that would make the buildings pop or light that would showcase the varying heights of the buildings.
 
 If there's a way to color correct, I think it would help this photo a lot. Make the sky more blue and the waters more blue-green and enticing. Give it the much needed contrast so the middle part becomes the highlight. 
 
 The details also need sharpening. Though it's a landscape shot, it wouldn't hurt to improve the sharpness of the image.

editing_action.action: Color correct the photo to make the sky more blue and the waters more blue-green.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests color correcting to make the sky and waters more vibrant, which falls under recoloring.

editing_action.action: Increase contrast to make the middle part of the photo the highlight.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests increasing contrast to highlight the middle part, making it an adjust contrast action.

editing_action.action: Improve the sharpness of the image.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests improving the sharpness, which is a superresolution action.

editing_action.action: Improve lighting to enhance the skyline.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the current lighting does not enhance the skyline, suggesting a need for relighting to improve the image.

shooting_action.action: Capture the photo during night or golden hour to make the buildings pop and showcase their varying heights.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests capturing the photo during night or golden hour to enhance the buildings and their varying heights, making it a timing-related shooting action.

action_concat:
Capture the photo during night or golden hour to make the buildings pop and showcase their varying heights.
Color correct the photo to make the sky more blue and the waters more blue-green.
Increase contrast to make the middle part of the photo the highlight.
Improve the sharpness of the image.
Make the photo feel more alive and interesting.
Improve lighting to enhance the skyline.

comment:
I'm not quite sure what this photo is about. What bothers me is how the woman almost blends in with the tree. Plus, she has her back to us, so we can't see her face. It looks a bit lifeless to me.
 
 The tree is also too big; it occupies the whole frame yet gives very little story. It's a whole lot of browns and dark greens with not much differentiation. The slanted angle also doesn't add much to the photo.
 
 I suggest a straightforward landscape shot that doesn't focus on the big tree. The woman could wear a more colorful dress so she pops, maybe something red. It would be more dynamic if she were mid-action, or if it were a more close-up shot of the woman with her face slightly turned to the right.

comment:
The image is overexposed. The lighting is harsh and doesn't highlight the gorgeous details of the balls.
 
 It would have been a fantastic shot if the colors were vibrant, where you could see the translucence of each ball.
 
 I suggest having a close-up shot of all the balls together, including the colorful sticks, instead of this angled shot. Have them altogether in one area and just do an overhead close-up shot. The balls could be scattered in a random manner, in different shapes and forms, to highlight the number and variety.
 
 Try to experiment with light as well. Maybe have half of them in overcast golden light while the other half is lit wholly by the warm light. This highlights the colors of the balls not only in colors but also in shadows.

editing_action.action: Enhance color vibrancy to reveal the translucence of the balls.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the colors are not vibrant and translucence is not visible, suggesting a need to enhance color vibrancy in post-processing.

shooting_action.reasoning: The comment mentions that the image is overexposed and the lighting is harsh, which implies the need to adjust exposure settings during shooting to better highlight details.

shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to take a close-up shot of all the balls and sticks together instead of an angled shot is a clear directive to change the composition.

shooting_action.action: Experiment with lighting by using overcast golden light and warm light to highlight colors and shadows.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests experimenting with different lighting conditions to enhance the colors and shadows, which is a lighting adjustment during shooting.

Take a close-up shot of all the balls and sticks together instead of an angled shot.
Experiment with lighting by using overcast golden light and warm light to highlight colors and shadows.
Adjust exposure and lighting to highlight the details of the balls.
Enhance color vibrancy to reveal the translucence of the balls.

comment:
First of all, I like to color contrast of the red shirt and the green background. Very cinematic. 
 
 However, the dead center subject doesn't look interesting. Maybe if he was bigger and closer it would make a difference, not this one where he's in a wide shot. 
 
 The edges of the mountains on top is also hazy and lacks clarity. It's overexposed and needs to have the brightness adjusted. I would also enhance the contrast so the trees are greener and darker. 
 
 I can also see this work well as a landscape shot. One where the man is enveloped by a whole lot of greenery, making him small in the vastness of nature.

editing_action.action: Enhance the contrast so the trees are greener and darker.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests enhancing the contrast to make the trees appear greener and darker.

shooting_action.action: Adjust the brightness to reduce overexposure.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly mentions that the image is overexposed and suggests adjusting the brightness to fix it.

shooting_action.action: Make the subject bigger and closer to increase interest.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment suggests that the subject being dead center is uninteresting and implies that changing the composition by making the subject bigger and closer would improve the image.

Make the subject bigger and closer to increase interest.

comment:
I quite like the intentional symmetry. This one would definitely look unreal as a black and white photo. That would make the lines, the edges, and the shapes pop.
 
 As it is, I would saturate the blue more so it would contrast nicely with the grays. I would also crop the bottom part of the image so the gray part of the building would be minimized. That will create more white space, which then balances the pronounced symmetry of the building.

comment:
This portrait looks like it was shot in a studio. It's clean. It's polished. It has artificial lighting doing its thing.
 
 It looks fine right now. Her face is well-lit, though nothing dramatic.
 
 I'd say the drama could be turned up a notch. Maybe play around with the position of the light source so half of the face is a bit hidden. I think it adds more interest instead of showing the whole face.
 
 I'd also much rather see a bit of delineation between the woman and the background instead of just floating in the black background. I think it's really a play on light and shadows.

comment:
The composition is not balanced. The subject is too close, and the tree in the background is too near the subject, with no other elements around.
 
 I would widen this shot, making the woman smaller and the background bigger. If it could be redone, have the subject walk towards something and capture the motion as much as you can. Also, I would include her whole body, or at least up to where I can see her limbs, to indicate movement.
 
 The bokeh effect was nicely captured, though. You can see the distinction between the subject and the background. The subject was just not that impactful.

comment:
The photo is quite dramatic. The low exposure creates a nice shadow and silhouette that makes the photo interesting.
 
 However, there's not much to the image apart from this. The color reminds me of The Batman. The woman looks like an old woman fervently praying.
 
 I would enhance the silhouette more by including the bottom silhouette of the woman. I would also minimize the enveloping blacks on the edges. Instead of a halo black effect, I'd play with the colors, changing them horizontally from reds to purples.
 
 On second thought, I think having the subject in the middle would also work here since it puts emphasis on the solo subject.

comment:
The image looks clear and crisp, with fantastic natural lighting.The colors are also true-to-life.
 
 I would definitely crop the space on the left so the first guy is more flushed to the left, emphasizing the way these people are lined up beside each other. I would include all their feet in the photo, plus a little bit more of the ground—a wider shot, in essence. Have the people be against a wider green background rather than right smack in the middle.
 
 If there was a greater depth of field, we could have the subject more pronounced against a blurrier background.

comment:
I understand the concept of this image. The point of view is definitely familiar. You look up and see the tall trees above you. I like the idea of the glaring light piercing through the branches.
 
 However, I think the glare on the left is too aggressive and distracts from the whole image. My gaze is blinded by this large glare. I would decrease this in post for sure.
 
 The composition also needs work. The distribution of the tree branches could be more scattered and not too close together. This could be achieved by using a wider lens. Also, since this captures an against-the-light look, try to find interesting angles of the branches. Make them your main subject instead of the trunks—those branches or leaves above that look dramatic as silhouettes. Basically, find a focal point, as this could easily get chaotic.

editing_action.action: Decrease the aggressive glare on the left in post-processing.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly mentions decreasing the aggressive glare on the left side in post-processing to reduce distraction.

shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests using a wider lens to achieve a more scattered distribution of tree branches, addressing the flaw of them being too close together.

shooting_action.action: Find interesting angles of the branches and make them the main subject as dramatic silhouettes.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly advises finding interesting angles of the branches and making them the main subject, emphasizing their dramatic silhouette against the light.

shooting_action.action: Find a focal point to avoid chaos in the composition.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly states the need to find a focal point to prevent the composition from becoming chaotic.

action_concat:
Decrease the aggressive glare on the left in post-processing.
Use a wider lens to scatter the distribution of tree branches.
Find interesting angles of the branches and make them the main subject as dramatic silhouettes.
Find a focal point to avoid chaos in the composition.

comment:
This portrait looks clean but also flat. Being in black and white, the contrast and saturation could easily veer towards one-dimensional. This could be remedied by playing with the source of your light, basically creating light and shadows so there's more depth and dimension.
 
 The subject is also too close. I'd step back a little and have him turn sideways, perhaps, or be more candid so he's not just flatly staring ahead.
 
 It's also interesting how I'm totally missing the eyes in this photo. It would have made a bigger impact, given that it is black and white. The shades are very limiting, in my opinion. He's filling up the entire frame, but there's not much story there. It'd be nice if we could see his eyes, have him look somewhere other than straight ahead, or have him be in motion, connecting to the surroundings.

comment:
Inspiring snowscape photography! The overall whiteness of the landscape contrasts the shadows and branches of the trees. Just by looking at the image, you could feel the cold breeze through the image. The vast emptiness of the white space gives off a modern feel for a landscape photograph. The color balance is spot on.
 
 I also love the cascading way the houses are lined up. Not in a straight line but going downhill. It's a unique way to capture the snowy hills.
 
 It's also breathtaking how the snow smoke was captured in the background. It looks so dynamic, almost like a painting. The composition is well-balanced as is. 
 
 Just a minor idea, what if the snow clouds cleared out a little bit. Maybe a little more peek of the mountains would elevate the photo more. But it's also arresting as it is, truth be told.

comment:
Great firework shot. I like how the fireworks can be seen on top of the building. It highlights how grand and massive the fireworks display was.
 
 Night photography can be tricky. Shooting at night can lose the details of your subject; in this case, the building and parking in your foreground are not as sharp as they could be, especially when you're shooting without a tripod. Using a tripod can greatly help with shooting at night. This will reduce noise and blurriness in the photo.
 
 The photograph might also be better if there was only one firework in the shot. In its current form, there are three fireworks in the composition, making it too chaotic. It still looks great, but it is a little chaotic.

Improve sharpness of the building and parking in the foreground.

comment:
Sunrise shots become derivative when not executed well. This photograph succeeds in sunset photography with its classic yet well-executed composition. 
 
 The sun is nicely placed on the side with a man looking in its direction. There's a great use of light and shadows contrasting throughout the frame. It's also incredible to see the varying degrees of golden light from bright yellow to orange to amber. The light is unbelievably gorgeous. However, the sun's glare can also come off too harsh here. I would suggest to wait until it's almost setting or it's still high above.
 
 It would also be really nice to see a peek of the person's face. A side angle that is lit up by this gorgeous light, perhaps showcasing a one eye that sparkles, would add drama to the image. Right now it's a whole lot of black with his back facing the camera.
 
 It would also be nice to see the ground below, whether they be trees or mountain sides. Just a bit more detail in that are would give texture to the whole image.

 The tree branches, especially the ones on the right, are distracting from the photo. They're almost dead center with nothing to offer the image.
 
 I think this would benefit from a symmetrical composition where the man and the zipline are shot dead center, and all the other elements—the trees, the leaves—serve as leading lines to the man on the zipline. It would also give the zipline emphasis, showcasing how long and nerve-wracking it supposedly is. Also, try to capture some distance or space between the main subject and the leading elements, perhaps showing the plants below the zipline, to emphasize the height of the zipline.

I like the attempt to use the tree's silhouette to showcase the warm rays of the sun.
 
 However, the tree is super imposing in this image. There's a little too much tree. It would be better if it weren't dead center.
 
 It would be better to create a wider landscape scene that would feature the whole area, including the car behind. The sunlight filtered through the lush and leafy branches would have had such a beautiful effect. You can already see a bit of this effect here. It just has to be more emphasized. This would create a wonderful shadow effect as the leaves are backlit by the sun.
 
 Right now, it's more like the tree is blocking the scene instead of scattering the gorgeous light of the sun.

comment:
There is something subversive about photographing colorful flowers in black and white. It's like the photographer has picked a lane, deciding to highlight the shape and texture of these flowers instead of their colors. In this case, it works so well! I love this image!
 
 I love how it's positioned slightly to the right with a little bit of white space on the left. This gives the photo a lot of balance and harmony. The flowers, in all their glory, are in focus. The ones on the left are sharp as a tack; you can see the contours, the layers, the beautiful flaps of flowers.
 
 My only critique is that I want to see this in full color as well. It just looks scrumptious.

The lighting is not flattering to the puppy. It looks like the photographer used flash, which appeared a little too harsh in the photo. He looks ashen and dirty instead of fluffy and creamy.

There needs to be more space up top so we can at least elongate the subject a little bit. It's still an interesting choice of angle because you are assuming the same position as the pet. Plus points for that. I just feel like it should have more breathing space up top to make the photo balanced.
 
 Finally, the bokeh effect could have worked quite nicely here. There should have been a greater depth of field so the puppy pops from the photo while the background blends into a creamy blur.

comment:
Great action shot! The biker is in mid-air and crystal clear, with the background wonderfully blurred. This is usually achieved using a fast shutter speed or continuous autofocus shooting, which allows you to capture and freeze the motion perfectly.
 
 The angle is also interesting, as this image was shot from below. This is a good choice because the rider's peak action is up in mid-air. By shooting from below, we emphasize the height that the bicycle just achieved.
 
 The downward direction of the ground below is a great leading element that signals direction and movement.
 
 One thing, though, is to remove the annoying brown tree trunk on the left-hand side. It's distracting, to say the least. Without it, we'll have a cleaner action shot.

comment:
I like that it looks so candid. She looks like she was caught off guard but smiled readily for the camera. It is more or less a snapshot. The pitch-black background is also jarring. It looks like she's floating or that she's a cutout.
 
 To improve this photo, I think the other people in the background can remain but be blurred out to highlight the main subject. Or they can be completely removed, and the main subject can be photographed somewhere that will still give context to where she is. Basically, have the subject interact with her surroundings or with the people she's surrounded by.
 
 For portraits of people, it's always nice to use the bokeh effect, which is achieved by using a wide aperture for a shallow depth of field. This makes the subject clear but their background soft and blurry.

comment:
At first glance, I thought it was a miniature waterfall. How could something so grand look so minute?
 
 Though a landscape shot would make sense here, I think it's better as a wider shot. You need a wide-angle lens to fully capture the whole image. The right-hand side needs to stretch a bit more so there is a flow to the picture. Right now, it looks stunted.
 
 There should also be more space above and below so that the falls look taller and more majestic, rather than short and cramped. The angle should also be from below so that the fall, again, looks taller.
 
 As with most nature photography, especially waterfall photography, it's indispensable to use a tripod and, ideally, a wide-angle lens.

comment:
The photo has no clear subject. It's a forest shot, but it doesn't highlight anything particularly interesting in the greenery. All the trees blur together in one green sweep; nothing stands out.
 
 It would be great to ask what exactly you want to capture here, and if you've decided on something, how would you capture it in your own unique and interesting way? We photograph to capture the world from our point of view.
 
 All this to say, this photo looks unintentional, and good photos are mostly intentional. We pick and choose what to include in the frame.
 
 To photograph a forest or a tree, I would find a way to showcase their height or their lush foliage. So either a wide-angle view that shows all of its grand beauty or a view from below looking up that highlights the green foliage of the tree against the sky. You can also try to find patterns that look interesting and try to show that in a focused, zoomed way, or in a multitude where they look like a plethora of similar shapes and forms.

comment:
This is a powerful action scene in bullfighting. It's good that we see the bullfighter in mid-air, about to be swiped by the bull.
 
 However, the composition needs work. Firstly, there's a weird haze around the bottom left, which looks like a hand on the lens. This shot needs to focus on the bullfighter and the bull. The background should be a bit blurred out to help the main subject stand out.
 
 In sports photography, you use a fast shutter speed to freeze the motion. You can also set your camera to autofocus continuous shooting and burst mode to capture many shots of the moving subject. It takes a lot of practice to anticipate action as it happens.

comment:
The sun is behind the woman, which is the main problem with this photo. We can't see her face, and part of her body is blurred by the glaring sun. All the details are eclipsed, and instead of having her as the focal point, we are simply blinded by the unfiltered sunlight. Even the low shooting angle doesn't help.
 
 Try to locate the light when shooting outdoors. This becomes obvious with the way the light hits your subject. It should illuminate, not obscure the subject. Usually, the most flattering is side lighting, as it's not too harsh. You can definitely explore other lighting angles, but back lighting does not work well, especially in portrait photography.

 This close-up shot lets us see the ox's beautiful hide. The colors look so creamy here—from the beiges to the deep browns. It's also amazing to see his full expression. He looks grim and menacing.
 
 What I would suggest here is to turn this into a portrait image. It should include the whole front part of the animal—the horns, the head, the torso, and the front legs—flushed lightly to the right with just enough blur at the left side of the image. I'd like to see this ox in full with the horns not cropped, still up close, still a tight shot, just not in landscape form.

shooting_action.action: Turn the image into a portrait format, including the whole front part of the animal with blur at the left side.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to turn the image into a portrait format and include specific parts of the animal is a clear instruction on how to arrange the visual elements within the frame, which falls under composition.

shooting_action.action: Capture the ox in full, with horns not cropped, in a portrait format.
shooting_action.reasoning: This action emphasizes capturing the entire ox without cropping the horns, which is a specific compositional adjustment to ensure the subject is fully included in the frame.

action_concat:
Turn the image into a portrait format, including the whole front part of the animal with blur at the left side.
Capture the ox in full, with horns not cropped, in a portrait format.

comment:
It's a good image because it features the subject quite nicely. She's slightly off-center but leaning casually onto the bridge. The colors look a little too artificial. I just think portraiture works best if the colors look realistic, meaning they look the same way as they are in real life, only in better natural lighting. This one almost looks like a cartoon character, not that it's entirely a bad thing.
 
 I appreciate the space afforded at the sides of the image. They give the image some breathing space, which makes it clean and airy, not messy and cramped.

editing_action.action: Make the colors look more realistic.

editing_action.action: Avoid making the subject look like a cartoon character.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the subject looks cartoonish due to color treatment, suggesting a need to adjust saturation or color balance to avoid this effect.

Make the colors look more realistic.
Adjust colors to look realistic, similar to real life but with better natural lighting.
Avoid making the subject look like a cartoon character.

comment:
This looks so ethereal, a feat considering it's shot in black and white. But that's exactly why it works.
 
 The scene is powerful because of the amazing and unique shapes and patterns of these bare tree branches. The composition is also very balanced, with much of the tall trees flushed to the right in contrast with the negative space on the left.
 
 The scene denotes a tranquil forest. All the elements together—the water, the branches, the fence, and the riverbank—look so harmonious together. It depicts serenity in nature.
 
 I would tweak the color temperature here and make it look cooler. I'd also deepen the shadows just to enhance the dimensions of the elements.

Deepen the shadows to enhance the dimensions of the elements.

 I would tighten this shot by minimizing the huge, unnecessary weeds on the right side of the photo. Just a few plants would work to frame it on this right side.
 
 I would also include more of the top part so it doesn't look stunted and abrupt. Some adjustments in the color and saturation would be nice. It's a nature photo, so it's nice to make the colors pop a bit more.

comment:
This is shot through a fish-eye lens, a bold choice. I'm not sure if it works here, though.
 
 However, what I noticed first and foremost is how underexposed this photo is. It looks like doom and gloom, and the water is no exception. The buildings also look warped.
 
 If this was the intention, seeing the overcast sky is right on theme. I suggest lessening the water area and focusing more on the buildings. I don't think a fish-eye lens does this scene justice; this needs a wide-angle lens that captures a broader view of a skyline image like this.
 
 Finally, why not just make it black and white? There are enough details here that would work well in black and white photography.

editing_action.reasoning: The comment mentions the buildings look warped, implying a need to correct this distortion.

editing_action.action: Convert the image to black and white.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests converting the image to black and white, indicating this as a desired enhancement.

Use a wide-angle lens to capture a broader view of the skyline.

comment:
What a powerful composition. It skillfully uses the building's colors and corners, the navy blue sky, and the people around it.
 
 I love how the figures are placed—one in the top right corner, another on the left, and a shadow silhouette near the bottom center. It distributes the visual weight quite nicely. This also beautifully complements the building's sharp triangular corners. The building's bold, layered colors contrast nicely with the sky's solid blue. Plus, the staircase blends perfectly with the building's corner in the middle.
 
 One improvement could be extending the top portion to highlight the roof area more prominently.

comment:

 This image would be greatly improved if there was some blurring of the trees and dilapidated railways in the background. Right now everything is clear, so the image definition [could be improved]. I would also crop the foreground a little bit just to enlarge the little girl more, but not a lot. It'd be nice to see her facial expression. I think that gives more of a story rather than this distant vantage point.

comment:
Even without a moving vehicle or a person in the image, it still looks alive and dynamic.
 
 The colors are what first grab your attention. They're so bold and vibrant, and they're peppered along the sides of the winding road.
 
 Speaking of the winding road, it's another beautifully done leading line. It's perfectly defined and perfectly placed in the middle, bringing us along the gorgeous tree-scape and the crystal-clear blue skies.
 
 I wouldn't change anything in this photo.

I love how motion was captured in this photo. There's a train track right in the middle, and the left road is filled with cars speeding by.
 
 Although it could be argued that the empty streets on the right provide a nice contrast to the busy cars on the left, I find the photo not so well-balanced because of that.
 
 I would rather shoot this in portrait orientation and focus on the two busy streets. You can use a motion blur technique to give drama to the vehicles passing by, or you can just use a faster shutter speed to freeze the motion of said vehicles.
 
 Either way, the goal is to elongate the orientation, which gives more emphasis to the length of the road amidst the tall buildings on the side.

shooting_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the photo is not well-balanced due to the contrast, suggesting a compositional adjustment.

shooting_action.action: Shoot in portrait orientation to focus on the two busy streets.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to shoot in portrait orientation is explicitly stated to focus on the busy streets, which is a compositional decision.

shooting_action.action: Use motion blur for drama or faster shutter speed to freeze vehicle motion.

shooting_action.reasoning: This action is explicitly stated as a compositional choice to emphasize the road's length.

Improve balance by addressing the contrast between busy and empty streets.

 I would also edit the colors and contrast here since the boy's skin tone appears a tad too pale.
 
 Other than that, it's a good portrait photo.

comment:
To capture a tall beverage, you need to be wary of the angle and the surroundings.
 
 Here, the slight top angle shot doesn't quite work. It could be shot straight at eye-level, capturing its height and content as realistically as possible. It would also be best to use the portrait orientation, especially if you are only photographing one drink.
 
 This indoor shot makes the photo underexposed. It doesn't highlight the color of the drink, the way the ice stacks up, or the fresh details of the sliced limes and lemons. It's always a good idea to photograph food in natural light.
 
 Or you can even make it more dynamic by having someone actually drink it so you can take an image with the hands of a person holding the drink.

shooting_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the indoor shot is underexposed, suggesting an improvement in exposure to highlight details.

shooting_action.action: Use portrait orientation when photographing a single drink.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly recommends using portrait orientation for photographing a single drink to improve composition.

shooting_action.action: Photograph food in natural light for better exposure.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly advises using natural light to improve exposure and highlight details.

shooting_action.action: Have someone hold the drink to make the image more dynamic.
shooting_action.reasoning: The suggestion to have someone hold the drink is implied to add dynamism to the photo, making it an implicit posing action.

action_concat:
Shoot the beverage at eye-level to capture its height and content realistically.
Use portrait orientation when photographing a single drink.
Photograph food in natural light for better exposure.
Improve exposure to highlight the color of the drink and details like ice and sliced limes and lemons.

 It's also confusing having two disparate elements right above each other. Are we focused on the flowers, or is it about the sunset? There's nothing that connects these two. They exist in two separate dimensions, and it doesn't make for a cohesive image.
 
 I would not waste that gorgeous light. I'd find a way to take photos of the flowers where they are lit by the sunlight. This would immediately improve the color, exposure, and quality of the image.

You can experiment with which parts of the skyline you photograph. The waterfall looks like one whole white blob, and the surrounding plants, moss, and rock are in a deep brown-green color that doesn't give any visual interest to the viewer. Also, the angle is too low, which makes the photo look short and stunted.
 
 I would step back and include more of the surroundings. It would be nice to include the body of water and find a way to imply movement using leading lines like the river flow, a series of winding shapes, or rock pathways.
 
 Try to make use of the best possible light, either on an overcast day or in the early mornings when the sun is not too harsh.

comment:
The vastness of the field beautifully contrasts with the calm blue sky, creating a scene that feels both expansive and serene. I love how everything in the photo appears so straight and orderly, giving it a clean and polished look. It's also amazing how there are essentially three layers to the image—the sky, the rock formations, the trees, and the yellow grass. They all harmoniously blend together to create a cohesive image.
 
 The electric lines, though subtle, lead your eyes through the image from left to right. The electric post gives such an interesting high point that breaks apart all the horizontal layers we have here.
 
 While the photo is already quite striking, a slight adjustment to the contrast could enhance its depth and bring out even more details, making the image truly captivating. These small tweaks can highlight the blend of natural colors, adding to the overall appeal.

 To enhance the sense of isolation and tranquility, expanding the photo slightly at the top and bottom could allow viewers to better appreciate the sailboats' solitary journey through the vast expanse of water. I like how this close-up shot of the cow makes it look like fabric. It's an unusual point of view that makes the viewer second guess what they're looking at. I love how the colors—beige, brown, and white—fill the whole frame, with the downturned eyes at the center of it all. It looks so unique and refreshing!
 
 What needs improvement here is the sharpness and contrast of the image. We're talking about details, up close, so it's important to have them sleek, crisp, and defined. It's not quite achieved here.  There's nothing more gorgeous than those water bubbles. It looks so fresh and inviting! The petals are also nicely focused. It's well-defined yet slowly blurs in the outskirts. Fantastic bokeh effect. The colors are vibrant. You can almost imagine how it smells and feels.
 
 If there's one thing I'd change, I would shoot this in landscape orientation. That way, there's more space for these gorgeous petals and enough negative space on the right to emphasize the minute details of the main subject.

comment:
Unfortunately, it's a very unflattering photo. The light is a bit harsh here, landing straight on her face, which is quite unforgiving. Plus, she's not ready for the photo, and it's not a good candid shot either way.
 
 The surrounding elements are also very random and chaotic.
 
 If there's one positive thing about it, it's that the image is very sharp and clear. The white balance also looks spot on. But again, it's not doing the subject any favors.
 
 If we're looking to do candid shots of people, it's standard to always try to capture them in their best light, usually lit sideways, or if it's front lighting, make sure they at least look their best. It's also standard to use a wide aperture to achieve that bokeh effect that looks fantastic in portraiture.

comment:
Such a cool shot, literally and figuratively! I love how cold and misty the image looks. You can definitely imagine what it feels like to be there.
 
 The composition is so pleasing to the eye. It's not too symmetrical, yet the elements are distributed very evenly, from the foreground to the background, to the hazy mountains at the back. Such incredible depth in this photo.
 
 I also appreciate the shape of the swamps. They curve with direction, giving not only a charming detail but also providing leading lines that pull you into the image.
 
 And let's stop and appreciate the shades of green in this image. What fascinates me is that it's not an overbearing shade at all. It's vibrant, yet not in your face. It's totally cool and soothing.
 
 Finally, I love how there are pops of pink flowers on the lower left side. They're so tiny, but they give the image some color, albeit in a very subtle way.
 
 I really don't have anything to add here except that I wish there were more pink flowers to see.

comment:
The subject looks a little tilted.
 
 I find the overall scene to be busy. There's a lot of texture featured here, but unfortunately, they seem too sharp and disparate. They don't really connect seamlessly with each other. It's the shiny metallic blue of the building's facade, then the thorny front canopy, and finally, the well-manicured green bushes at the bottom. They have distinct shapes and textures, but they don't look pleasing or captivating.
 
 Though the curved line above the building looks interesting, it doesn't really add anything to the photo.
 
 I think it would be wise to focus on the reflected image, or perhaps do a shot of the blue metallic tiles that make up the building's facade. I think that would make for a fascinating multitude shot.
 
 I would also adjust the brightness here. It comes off a little too harsh, and that doesn't help all the rugged edges already present in the photo.

Yet, it turns out there's a road right beside it that serves as a fantastic leading line, taking you from the front to the back of the photo. I appreciate that it's not too obvious at first but works quite well in making the photo look visually balanced.
 
 I also like how there's a blurry line in the foreground, which suggests this was taken from a window above. I don't find it distracting. It's nice that it's implied rather than forced.
 
 I do think there's a need to adjust the sharpness, contrast, and saturation of this photo. It doesn't look as defined as it should be. It would also be nice to play around with the color temperature and see what would make the streetlights and yellow lights pop out even more. The photo just needs more definition and polish.

The surrounding moss-covered rocks did not help either. If there were interesting shapes and curves in these rocks, they are surely not showcased here.

comment:
That is one eerie photo!
 
 What I find uneasy here is what has been omitted from the frame. The way her head is positioned conjures a number of undesirable scenarios in my head. What is going on with her? It doesn't help that the background looks like the forest floor.
 
 And it's also scary how the woman's mouth looks half-open, half a smirk. She also has a blank gaze—totally strange and frightening.
 
 This is a good example of how what you leave out of the frame is as important as what you include in it.
 
 It's also a strange choice to have the right-hand side blurred and the left-hand side clear. Her hair is particularly in focus, but as far as I'm concerned, the main subject is still the woman's head. It's amazing how the blurred part also draws your interest, all because it's larger and is the more arresting part of the photo.
 
 For the unsettling effect that this photo has on the viewer, I'd give it a high rating. The composition, as unusual as it is, has at least achieved one of the more disturbing photos I've ever seen.

comment:
I'm distracted by the lens flare in this photo. This is caused when stray light from a very bright source, like the sun, infiltrates the internal parts of the camera, such as the lens, sensors, and filters. Some of that light is reflected back out and causes these random flares in the image.
 
 The foreground here also looks too dark and becomes a visually heavy part of the photo with not much visual interest. When taking a photo of the sun, it's best to find an angle that doesn't directly point the lens at it. Try to find ways where the sun can be filtered in a natural setting, say amongst tree leaves and branches.
 
 In this case, wait for the sun to move just a little more so it's not directly pointed at the camera lens, or you can try to capture the rays through the plants and shrubbery below. Find a focal point that has a lot of texture, form, and interesting details so it creatively showcases the sun's rays.

Though it does have a different effect, like the shadows of the boats, I think when the sun was a little higher, this scene was lit in a more interesting way. Right now, it looks more underexposed than anything else.
 
 Also, the composition isn't well-balanced. The boats don't fully pull the viewer into the scene, as they look too small and random. I suggest finding a different angle where there's a bigger boat or two in the foreground, which could act as the main anchor of the photo, surrounded by more boats all around it.  I would also consider the horizon, as it usually becomes the midline section of a photo like this. When the sun is about to set, use a tripod to capture the ever-changing skyline and see what you like best. It should add interest to the image, not distract from it. It should have colors or patterns that complement the other elements around it.

 The sky, with its intense contrast, tends to overwhelm the rest of the composition, drawing attention away from the calmness of the overall landscape.
 
 However, there's something captivating about how your eyes are drawn to the river flowing through the center of the image. This feature creates a natural pathway for the viewer's gaze, adding depth and interest.
 
 The greens are lush and vibrant, but some areas are overly contrasted, which can detract from their organic charm. By gently reducing the saturation, the photo could achieve a more balanced and inviting look. This subtle adjustment would enhance the overall harmony and make the scene more engaging.
 
 It's also nice to straighten the middle ground (the island with the trees). The photo would look so much more polished than its current tilted version.

comment:
The photo is too cluttered. Although the stuffed toy is obviously in the middle, there are a lot of competing elements, like the desk fan, the pens, some books, and sticky notes. It's a very busy scene.
 
 There are also many different light sources here. There's the natural light and the glare of the computer screen.
 
 If the photographer wanted to focus on the stuffed toy, he/she should use a shallow depth of field to isolate the main subject and blur the rest of the background. If it is a work table scene, we should see the rest of the furniture—basically, a complete interior shot.
 
 But for particular objects, it's best to isolate the image or put it in a place that looks natural. For a stuffed toy, possibly with other toys or in a cabinet. This gives a much better concept and a more coherent image.

 However, the image looks too sharp and contrasted, to the point that the sharpness looks unnatural and harsh. It's also a tad overexposed.

 I appreciate how the snow looks multidimensional. If we just lessen the brightness, I think we can see more definition on the curves and crannies of the snow.

comment:
The photo is overexposed. As beautiful as the golden light is, there is just too much of it in this photo. The glare hurts my eyes, and it also makes it harder to appreciate the details and nuances. Everything is blinded and distracted by the sun. It doesn't help that it's right in the middle, too.
 
 This image could be improved by adjusting the brightness. When photographing the sun, it's best not to shoot directly at it. Aside from being dangerous, it can also cause lens flare or overexposed photos.
 
 It's recommended to try to filter the sun using the natural elements around it, like the island, the clouds, or the trees.
 
 In this example, I would wait until it doesn't look too harsh anymore. Wait until it has moved downwards a little bit and try to see how it reflects off the water instead. The man could also be in motion, like walking away instead of just standing.

 The stair handle in the foreground is a nice leading line that leads the audience to the rest house. It's not a distracting line at all.
 
 My main adjustment here would be the overexposed light inside the house. Tone it down a bit. It should still look bright and welcoming, but not blinding.

 You could also showcase the different lights available in this area and make it look like a slice-of-life photo. It would be even better if the people you photograph are in motion. This takes patience, a tripod, and a good camera lens that can accommodate low-light situations.

 The goal is to showcase the skyline, its details, the buildings, and the busy scene amidst the backdrop of the golden sun.

comment:
I get what the photographer is doing here. A photo from the car's rearview mirror can look really cool with the right angle and the right composition.
 
 In this case, the angle feels too cramped, and there are a lot of distracting elements that obscure the intended subject. Although, as it stands, the subject is also not clear here. Is it the backyard? Or is it the skeleton sticker?
 
 I think the first challenge here is to actually find an interesting subject. Since there's very little area to showcase, it's ideal to choose something expansive and not easily swallowed by all the other elements in the image. Basically, you're trying to frame a scene inside another scene.
 
 It's usually more impactful if it creates an iteration, like the sun setting reflected in an open road and also reflected alongside the bigger picture. It's also tricky to achieve that "fits-the-whole-puzzle" look, where the reflected image is part of the bigger image. This type of composition needs a lot of practice and experimentation, but that's also what makes it really fun!

Right now, it looks like a zoom shot of a textured green fabric. The problem is that it has a very shallow depth of field for something that should be sharper. If we're trying to do a macro shot of something, it's important to choose a focal point to highlight. Here, there is nothing that stands out; everything just blends into the background. There's nothing of different height, texture, or even color.
 
 If we really have to photograph this scene, I would suggest a crystal clear close-up shot, possibly shot from a top angle, to see it from multiple points of view. It should show the similarity in pattern and color. From this angle, there is not much to show since it's too minute and flat.

 I love how it's ultra-focused on his face. You can see all the beautiful details of his patterned fur, his green eyes, his unperturbed mouth, and his snowy white whiskers.
 
 I would, however, like to see his ears too. It would make the image more impactful, though I completely understand why this was shot this close.
 
 It's amazing how crystal clear the details are. You can almost touch and feel them. It's also interesting how the shadows obscure his other eye, giving him more interest and dimension.
 
 This photo could also work in portrait orientation, which would be more forgiving in terms of including his ears and possibly his torso. But that would also be a totally different image.

comment:
Not really sure why this looks tilted. I know it's a chandelier, but the choice to frame it in this cramped manner doesn't make any sense.
 
 The chandelier is a source of light on its own. It's very detailed and usually comes in big, ostentatious sizes like this one. I agree that it would be nice to capture it in low light where the chandelier's own light would actually stand out. But in this case, the shot doesn't do it justice.
 
 The first consideration would be the size and shape of the chandelier. If it's huge like this one, I would make it the centerpiece of the photo. Have it occupy a large portion of the frame and make sure the lights pop out. Try to use a small aperture and fast shutter speed so you'll capture the details.
 
 If it's delicate, thin, and broad, maybe experiment with shooting from below. It would be nice to find patterns in the chandelier that you could highlight.

comment:
Great shot overall!
 
 Reflection photography usually involves a clear reflection of the landscape to depict symmetry.
 
 The reflection is almost there. Although I like that it's not a totally clear reflection like most shots that incorporate this style. I like that it's more implied than a clear mirror image. It's subtle and suggestive.
 
 However, to achieve a clear reflection, make sure all your camera settings are correct. Usually, this type of photography uses a small aperture and a fast shutter speed. Another trick is to focus on the reflection in the water rather than the real subject. Usually, the camera already picks up the subject closest to it. So when you try to set your focus, set it to focus on the water instead, so it gives you more chances of having a clear reflection.
 
 I also suggest giving some breathing space on the right-hand side of this photo. This can be achieved by stepping back a little and including more of the scene. Right now, there is also a distracting black entity on the right-hand side that needs to be edited.

editing_action.action: Edit out the distracting black entity on the right-hand side.
editing_action.reasoning: The action involves removing a distracting element from the photo, which is an editing action related to deleting.

shooting_action.action: Ensure camera settings are correct, use a small aperture and fast shutter speed.
shooting_action.reasoning: The action involves adjusting camera settings to achieve a clear reflection, which is a shooting action related to exposure.

shooting_action.action: Focus on the reflection in the water rather than the real subject.
shooting_action.reasoning: The action involves changing the focus point to enhance the reflection, which is a shooting action related to focus.

shooting_action.action: Step back to include more of the scene and give breathing space on the right-hand side.
shooting_action.reasoning: The action involves changing the composition by stepping back to include more of the scene, which is a shooting action related to composition.

action_concat:
Ensure camera settings are correct, use a small aperture and fast shutter speed, and focus on the reflection in the water.
Step back to include more of the scene and give breathing space on the right-hand side.
Edit out the distracting black entity on the right-hand side.

comment:
The first thing that comes to mind is how lovely this photo would be if it were in landscape orientation. The expanse would just be perfect in a horizontal frame.
 
 The photo is minimalist, yet it's not devoid of impact. I love how the grass was captured here. It doesn't look flat at all. You can see the texture, the height differences, and the deep and shallow areas as evidenced by the number of shadows in it. You can see the texture, maybe not in a closeup way, but from afar.
 
 Then there's the stark blue sky from above that looks like an alien has just landed. There are even very tiny beings who seem to be walking in the direction of the light—very interesting details, but also very tiny. I wish they were bigger so we wouldn't have to squint our eyes.
 
 I would probably tweak the brightness of this photo just to check if it would have more impact. It's a tad overexposed and could use a dial down a notch or two.

comment:
The colors of the image look dull. It feels like there's a hazy filter over it, which makes the photo look blurred, undefined, and cluttered. It doesn't help that there is no breathing room on either side; it's just end-to-end buildings and infrastructure. The midline is also tilted, and there is nothing that catches the eye.
 
 First, the midline should be straightened just so it looks a little bit polished.
 
 Second, I suggest trying to shoot at a time of day when the sun will illuminate this scene in an interesting way, say, the golden hour or early morning. It needs some experimentation. You'll know because you yourself would gasp at the beautiful light.
 
 Third, make sure to use a wide-angle lens so that you capture the details and can choose to have a broader frame to work with.
 
 Fourth, try to find a set of buildings that has some visual interest, whether it's shaped in a wonky way, has beautiful architecture, or looks unique alongside other buildings. Otherwise, it would really look mundane, especially if the lighting is also flat and mediocre.
 
 Fifth, edit your photo by enhancing the brightness, contrast, and saturation with the goal of cleaning up the image and making the elements stand out.

Instead of the usual from-below shot, this one makes the buildings seem small and toy-like. I appreciate the creativity.
 
 Now, on to the execution. I find that the composition looks awkward. There seems to be a reversal here, as the foreground contains all the tall elements while the background is smaller and shorter. It's anticlimactic for the viewer.
 
 I also don't agree with where it's cropped, especially the bottom part of the image. There is no clear angle or framing that guides the eye to where the image starts and ends. It's just that the buildings are sprouting in a random manner.
 
 I think a portrait orientation could help narrow down the scope of this scene. It will also give some much-needed focus so that we see a more cohesive version. Choose which buildings to highlight in this scene.
 
 Make sure to enhance the sharpness and contrast so there is definition among the buildings. The light is a bit overexposed here, so that also needs some toning down. If it has to stay in landscape orientation, I suggest tilting the camera downwards to include more of the buildings' lower portion.

comment:
Love this image! It's so vogue!
 
 The stark white background and the stark white pillow where the cat's resting are sublime. Both make for the perfect canvas, making this elegant-looking cat stand out!
 
 I love how her torso and her paws meld a little bit into the white sofa. It's so seamless and creamy. I even like how her paws are resting. They have levels. One is outstretched, and the other is closed off. The way she's leaning gives a lot of attitude, just like how cats really are. Even her expression is so nonchalant, almost bored.
 
 This is also a good example of a narrow depth of field. The cat's face is in full focus, while the rest of the image blends creamily into the background.
 
 I appreciate how clear her features are. It's sharp and not overdone.
 
 If I have to nitpick, I would edit or even crop just a tiny bit around the upper right-hand corner so it looks completely white. Apart from that, it really is perfect!

comment:

 Whatever this is, I haven't seen anything like it. It looks like charcoal art or an x-ray. Bravo for creativity, but I just don't get it, sadly. The elements aren't that visually interesting to me. Apart from the tree branches, the right foreground is almost unrecognizable. Is it burnt? It just looks black right now.
 
 I can imagine if the details were as intricate as the branches and the ones on the upper left-hand side, I think it would look cool. It's essentially like shadow play. However, this image, as is, missed the mark for me.

comment:
It's an interesting photo. However, it looks too busy. There are no leading lines and there's just too much going on—we have the bicycles on foreground, the woman walking past, a sidewalk, an intersection with vague silhouettes of more people, another building across the street. It's a lot.
 
 What I appreciate here is the striking shade of black used. It's a beautiful shade, you can see it especially in the bikes which are in focus. Apart from that, the composition needs to be heavily edited. I would think it's the woman who should be the subject of this image. I would shift my focus on her and photograph her walking towards the intersection. I'd skip the bikes.
 
 But if it's the bikes that's the subject of this image, then focus on that. This angle can still be used but make sure the bikes occupy a bigger part of the frame.

comment:
It's a candid shot of people at a cookout. The image looks interesting but needs a few tweaks.
 
 First, the composition feels busy and unbalanced. There are a lot of competing elements that don't really strengthen the scene. There's even a forklift in the background, and there appear to be barricades, too.
 
 It would help if the two people were moved a little bit to the right, and the background blurred out, even just a little. Leave things like the grill and the table, as they provide great context to the image. It's also better if the people aren't at the same level right next to each other. Either they are interacting, in the middle of cooking, or at least one is on lower ground, so it looks more dynamic.
 
 I do appreciate that it looks un-staged, like a documentary shot.

comment:
I love the color of the sky here. It's a lovely shade of purple that works well with the green silhouette of the trees.
 
 The main issue here is taking a direct photo of the sun. It's a common issue that causes lens flare, the one encircled in pink.
 
 Lens flare happens when a very strong light source hits the camera lens and scatters and bounces off the internal parts of the camera, like the aperture and sensor. This results in what you see in this photo: a white halo, dot, or haze in the resulting image.
 
 There are a number of ways to avoid this, and the most common is a lens hood, or you can even simply use your hand over the lens to block the sunlight. Or, you can change the angle so it doesn't hit the lens directly.
 
 In this case, I would also change the angle of the camera. Try not to have the sun dead center in the photo. It would work to focus on the branches and the patterns they create amidst this stark, high sunlight.

shooting_action.action: Use a lens hood or hand to block sunlight, or change the angle to avoid direct sunlight on the lens.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests using a lens hood or hand to block sunlight or changing the angle to prevent lens flare, which falls under the Lens category as it involves controlling light entering the lens.

shooting_action.action: Change the camera angle to avoid having the sun dead center and focus on the branches and patterns.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly advises changing the camera angle to avoid having the sun in the center and to focus on branches and patterns, which is a Camera Position action.

shooting_action.action: Avoid taking direct photos of the sun to prevent lens flare.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment implicitly suggests avoiding direct photos of the sun to prevent lens flare, which is a Lens-related action as it involves managing light interaction with the lens.

action_concat:
Use a lens hood or hand to block sunlight, or change the angle to avoid direct sunlight on the lens.
Change the camera angle to avoid having the sun dead center and focus on the branches and patterns.
Avoid taking direct photos of the sun to prevent lens flare.

I find this angle for a portrait shot quite unique. However, it's hard to appreciate her facial features at this angle. I think it would have worked better in reverse, meaning her head would be on the upper left side of the frame and her torso on the lower right side. That way, we wouldn't have to twist our vantage point to see her face.
 
 Her hands also look a little stiff, which makes me wonder how comfortable she actually is.
 
 As for her facial expression, I don't really get much emotion from her. Her eyes are almost squinting, so there's not much to glean from there.
 
 In terms of color, I like how the orange complements the camouflage pattern of the rock. However, I don't think the low saturation does her skin tone any favors. It looks a little sallow, almost pale and grey. I would definitely adjust the saturation and color temperature of this photo.

comment:
My eyes are immediately drawn to the beautiful orange flowers in the foreground. They're so lush!
 
 Then the rest of the scene eventually grew on me. At first, I found it distracting to have the sea also in sharp focus, as it distracts from the flowers. But the more I look at it, the more I appreciate the layers of mother nature on display here.
 
 We have the sky, the sea, the rocks, the flowers, and the greenery. That's a bounty in one image.
 
 What I would change here is the levels of these layers. I think it would look really great to have the sky be bigger than the rest of the scene. This would mean that the flower area needs to be cropped and the blue sky needs to be extended above. That way, we have some negative space to balance the heaviness of the entire rest of the scene.

 I think this would be more compelling if the panoramic shot was focused on the left side of this image. It has more visual interest, and it would be nice to see it more in focus rather than this very tiny version. The two sides just don't feel cohesive.

comment:
Now, that is just blurry. It hurts my eyes.
 
 The elements are actually quite charming. The series of orange dots amidst the dark blue sky looks so interesting, but again, it's blurred and not in an intentional kind of way.
 
 To avoid this much blur, always consider the scene you're trying to capture. If it's a nature scene like this—a sky, to be specific—a capable wide-angle lens is best. If you don't have that, just make sure that your camera settings are correct: low aperture, fast shutter speed, and ideally a low ISO, depending on the light you currently have. This allows you to take sharper photos of things that are far from your camera lens.
 
 If this wasn't blurred, I would also add some negative space in this image—something that would break the whole branches-in-the-sky scene because it looks too heavy right now. It's very appealing, it just needs to be edited so it looks balanced in the frame.

shooting_action.action: Reduce blur to improve clarity.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment mentions the image is blurry, implying the need to improve focus for clarity.

shooting_action.action: Ensure intentional use of blur.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment suggests the blur is unintentional, implying the need for intentional focus adjustments.

shooting_action.action: Use a capable wide-angle lens for nature scenes like the sky.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests using a wide-angle lens for capturing nature scenes like the sky.

shooting_action.action: Ensure correct camera settings: low aperture, fast shutter speed, and low ISO.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly advises on camera settings to achieve sharper photos.

shooting_action.action: Add negative space to balance the composition.
shooting_action.reasoning: The comment explicitly suggests adding negative space to improve the composition.

action_concat:
Consider the scene to avoid excessive blur.
Use a capable wide-angle lens for nature scenes like the sky.
Ensure correct camera settings: low aperture, fast shutter speed, and low ISO.
Add negative space to balance the composition.
Reduce blur to improve clarity.
Ensure intentional use of blur.

The pink and purple hues in the background look so pretty. This scene reminds me of camping trips. It looks like we have a tent here. The sun has set, and we have a night lamp in preparation for nightfall.
 
 I also love how the trees in the background frame the lamp nicely.
 
 The image is blurred, but I don't think this scene calls for crystal-clear images. It's a mood shot, and you can sometimes get away with a little blur. It's just a fact that in an incredibly low-light situation, only a tripod would yield clear and sharp images. I think a few tweaks in sharpness would greatly improve this image.

comment:
This nature shot is not as compelling as it could have been.
 
 The portrait orientation is not suitable here; the photo looks cramped. The background elements are also too dark, almost underexposed. We need to see more of the scene and more implications of the water's flow.
 
 The shadows here don't work as well because the photo looks flat.
 
 If it were a wider shot, I think we could see other supporting elements that would make the mini waterfall shine in the image—perhaps the trees surrounding this river, wildflowers, or even huge rocks that would give more context to the current subject.
 
 Also, to ensure a motion freeze for the waterfall, the camera settings should have a fast shutter speed and a low aperture. You can also use the continuous shooting mode so you'll have lots of options later.

editing_action.action: Brighten the background elements to avoid underexposure.
editing_action.reasoning: The comment implies that the background elements are too dark, suggesting an adjustment to brighten them and avoid underexposure.
